video.title: The Roottrees Are Dead and Ender Magnolia: Bloom in the Mist | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
Man, bollocks to you, current events. I&#39;m 
pausing so you can cut that bit out and

post it as a funny meme on social media every 
day for the next four years. I&#39;m bored with

being coy about my political stances, so for the 
record, if you voted for that orange knob-end,

I hope he mashes your family up into paste 
and uses you as part of his skincare regimen.

But why let it take over our lives? Let&#39;s 
cheer ourselves up with a nice aspirational

game about billionaires getting completely 
fucked up. The Roottrees are Dead is a—brace

yourself—genealogical deduction game that 
opens with the news that the president of

an ultra-successful family candy corporation 
has died in a freak plane crash along with

his spouse and all of his heirs. Oh, what a 
shame. If only it had been in an imploding,

poorly designed deep sea submersion 
vehicle, I could&#39;ve actually reached climax,

but I guess that wasn&#39;t on the cards &#39;cause 
the game&#39;s set in 1998 back when things made

sense and there was still some measure of respect 
towards the sanctity of human life. We play as a

professional genealogist who has to interrupt 
their nonstop life of glamour and sex to figure

out the careless twat&#39;s entire family tree going 
back four generations and figure out what random

scattered cousins are about to inherit enough 
cash to goldplate their newly erect todgers.

Sounds easy? Well, did you miss the part 
that we&#39;re set in 1998 and the only tool

at our disposal is the pre-social media internet 
before everyone on Earth thought it necessary to

document their every passing sandwich, and 
you can only find people online if they&#39;ve

been in the news or have gotten their clothes 
off in a professional setting? Gameplay-wise,

you go to the &quot;cups on the ends of strings&quot; 
90s-era internet typing in search terms,

and from the initial crumbs of information go down 
multiple deep rabbit holes to take pictures of

the rabbits in their most intimate moments. Very 
Hypnospace Outlaw-esque. And after coming up for

air, you toddle off to the Roottree family... 
tree and fill each en...tree with a photo,

a profession, and an identi-tree, and every time 
you have tree—I mean three—or four fully correct,

they get locked in with a little congratulation 
ceremony, very Return of the Obra Dinn-esque. Now,

forgive me if I&#39;ve failed to adequately bring 
this across in the multiple years I&#39;ve spent

screaming and banging you over the head with 
it, but I really like Return of the Obra Dinn;

that&#39;s probably why this game was recommended 
to me so highly, thinking about it.

But it was because of the Obra Dinn comparison 
that, while I was cutting out pictures of some

cockhead used car salesman and his two 
extremely embarrassed-looking daughters,

I found myself thinking, &quot;Man, I wish someone 
would get eaten by a kraken.&quot; You see,

while the game pulls off the satisfaction of 
figuring out puzzles with your amazing brain,

it falls short of highly recommended &#39;cause it 
lacks for a secret spice, e.g., kraken massacre.

There&#39;s a hint about some dark family secret that 
will be revealed in time, but when it is revealed,

I was like, &quot;That&#39;s it? No one got murdered? No 
one got pulled apart by tentacles?&quot; You&#39;re aware

of my definition for &quot;post-dad games&quot;; that is, 
the dad game&#39;s satisfaction with a job well done

combined with a fantastical narrative streak, 
like a lawnmower that talks with the voice

of Gilbert Gottfried? While I do recommend 
Roottrees to fellow deduction game enjoyers,

it doesn&#39;t get as far as the &quot;post&quot; in post-dad. I 
think it might just be a dad-dad game. A newspaper

puzzle page writ large. And the fact that that 
turns me off slightly gives me a strange hope.

Maybe I haven&#39;t gone fully dadbrained yet. Maybe 
there&#39;s still time to avoid my gut ballooning out

over the top of my overly tight jeans so I look 
like a giant capital P when standing in profile.

Phew, I feel relevant again. Let&#39;s play a cocking 
Soulslike. One with an anime art style like what

all us young people like. Oh, here&#39;s one: a new 
sequel to Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights

called Ender Magnolia: Bloom in the Mist. More 
like &quot;we got bloomin&#39; pissed when we were coming

up with the names for these things.&quot; You may 
remember Bender Sillies: Flatus of the Shites

was a Soulslike Metroidvania about the last days 
of a dying dark fantasy world. &quot;Yahtzee—&quot; Yes,

I know; I&#39;m about to narrow it down. This was the 
2D one where we play as an adorable, pristine,

innocent girly-wirl who enlists the spirits of 
all the dudes she defeats and lets them do all the

combat while she holds the coats and completes 
the tax paperwork. Sort of the intersection

between Alice in Wonderland, Salt and Sanctuary, 
and JoJo&#39;s Bizarre Adventure. So what&#39;s new for

Bender Begonias: Bloody Bleeding Blimey? Well, not 
a whole lot, actually. Again, we play as pristine,

innocent girly who wakes up in a coffin at the 
bottom of a sprawling Metroidvania map; again,

we enlist the spirits of defeated monsters and 
warriors to wipe our delicate bumsy in combat;

and the main antagonistic force is a 
nondescript, corrupting, black fart

cloud simply called &quot;The Blight,&quot; although 
it might as well have been called &quot;The Plot.&quot;

The main difference is that we&#39;ve switched from 
fantasy to sci-fi. And if you genuinely can&#39;t

think of anything to do but a retread of your last 
game, that is always a reliable sequel pipeline,

good enough for Warhammer, Castlevania, Lords of 
Shadow, and, er, that Gilligan&#39;s Island spinoff

cartoon where they went to space. So now, 
instead of purifying the souls of knights,

we&#39;re reprogramming corrupted robots and turning 
them into digital ghosts like they&#39;re Pokémon or

something, making this more the intersection 
between Salt and Sanctuary, JoJo&#39;s Bizarre

Adventure, and NieR: Automata. But I can&#39;t 
be too salty because, like its predecessor,

I rather enjoyed Ender Magnum PI. It&#39;s 
just a nice, functional Metroidvania.

Not exactly setting a fire under the genre; 
the Start to Double-Jump rating is, like,

three rooms, but there&#39;s something comforting 
about the reliable way all the cogwheels click

together. The easily readable art style; the 
nice, helpful map that highlights rooms that

still have undiscovered secrets so you know 
where to come back to when you unlock the

head-mounted secret opening device. And 
the combat&#39;s rather enjoyable as well.

You can fully customize what Stand attacks 
are mapped to the four attack buttons and have

them all cracking off at the same time 
with no stamina mechanic to limit you,

and when you can summon a whirling ball of damage 
at will, including that one terribly useful Stand

who has mastered the secret martial art known 
as owning a gun, the bosses were pretty easy,

mostly only taking two or three attempts 
before folding like the center pages of the

boys dormitory&#39;s only issue of Playboy. Comboing 
different attacks at the same time can take a

little bit of uncomfortable finger origami, but 
as I say, you can map the buttons how you like,

so just find whatever works best when you mash 
the controller with your palm. My only major

strike against Endlessly Mangled Title is that 
I really couldn&#39;t follow the plot. Part of the

standard Soulslike format is to drop you into 
the middle of dying, apocalyptic world du jour

and hint at the story with confusing background 
crumbs. Ender Magnolia opts instead to hint at

the story with prolonged dialogues between 
characters while you glance between them,

not understanding what in the name of Beelzebub&#39;s 
bellend they&#39;re banging on about. I guess we are

playing as a kid. Maybe that&#39;s the intention. 
To evoke how it felt to be in the room when my

dad was refusing to explain to my mum what he 
was doing at a bar called the Rusty Trombone.
